skill.name: matchms
skill.description: Spectral similarity and compound identification for metabolomics. Use for comparing mass spectra, computing similarity scores (cosine, modified cosine), and identifying unknown compounds from spectral libraries. Best for metabolite identification, spectral matching, library searching. For full LC-MS/MS proteomics pipelines use pyopenms.
skill.summary: Spectral similarity and compound identification for metabolomics. Use for comparing mass spectra, co...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: The static analyzer incorrectly flagged documentation code blocks as security issues. All findings are false positives - the 'weak cryptographic algorithm' and 'external commands' alerts stem from markdown documentation containing code examples and legitimate URLs to scientific resources. No actual security risks were found.

content.user_title: Analyze Mass Spectrometry Data for Metabolite ID
content.value_statement: Mass spectrometry data contains complex spectral information that requires specialized processing. Matchms provides comprehensive tools to import, filter, and compare mass spectra for metabolite identification and compound analysis.
actual_capabilities: Import/export spectra from MGF, mzML, MSP, JSON formats
Calculate cosine similarity and modified cosine scores
limitations: Requires Python environment with matchms installed
Chemical structure processing requires RDKit dependency

use_cases.title: Identify unknown metabolites
use_cases.description: Compare experimental spectra against reference libraries to identify unknown compounds in metabolomics studies.

use_cases.title: Process LC-MS/MS data
use_cases.description: Import raw mass spec data, apply quality filters, and prepare spectra for downstream analysis.

use_cases.title: Build spectral matching pipelines
use_cases.description: Create automated workflows for large-scale spectral comparison and compound identification.

prompt_templates.title: Basic spectrum loading
prompt_templates.prompt: Load spectra from my MGF file and show basic statistics about the dataset

prompt_templates.title: Apply quality filters
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply default filters to normalize intensities and remove low-quality peaks from my spectra

prompt_templates.title: Spectral library search
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare my query spectra against a reference library using cosine similarity and return top 5 matches

prompt_templates.title: Build processing pipeline
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a SpectrumProcessor pipeline that applies metadata harmonization, intensity normalization, and peak filtering

best_practices: Always apply default_filters first to harmonize metadata
Use appropriate similarity functions (CosineGreedy for speed, ModifiedCosine for precursor differences)
Validate results with chemical standards when possible
anti_patterns: Skipping quality filters before similarity calculations
Using inappropriate similarity metrics for your data type

faq.question: What file formats does matchms support?
faq.answer: MGF, MSP, mzML, mzXML, JSON (GNPS), Pickle, and USI references.

faq.question: Which similarity metric should I use?
faq.answer: Use CosineGreedy for general matching, ModifiedCosine when precursor masses differ.

faq.question: Do I need RDKit for all features?
faq.answer: Only for chemical structure processing (SMILES, InChI conversions).

faq.question: How do I handle large spectral libraries?
faq.answer: Use batch processing and consider memory-efficient similarity calculations.

faq.question: Can matchms identify unknown compounds?
faq.answer: Yes, by comparing against reference spectral libraries using similarity scores.

faq.question: What's the difference between mzML and MGF?
faq.answer: mzML contains raw instrument data, MGF is processed peak lists for analysis.
